Master data (business objects)

Master data (business objects)

Master data is the stable reference layer that bookkeeping relies on when it turns operational events into ledger postings and period-based reports. The goal is that invoices, bank transactions, documents, and postings can all be scoped correctly, classified consistently, and reviewed later without guesswork. All master data that a module owns is stored in the workspace root (the effective working directory) only; BusDK does not store master data under subdirectories.

This section describes the business objects and the bookkeeping properties they need. The descriptions are concept-level and intentionally avoid implementation details so the same objects and properties can also support adjacent use cases such as CRM, procurement, and document management.

Use case index

Bookkeeping foundations (shared across workflows)

  • Accounting entity: The bookkeeping scope defined by the workspace directory boundary, keeping journals, VAT, and reports separated per business entity.
  • Chart of accounts: The ledger accounts and reporting structure used for posting and review.
  • VAT treatment: The minimal VAT metadata that makes posting and VAT reporting deterministic.
  • Parties (customers and suppliers): The counterparties attached to invoices, transactions, and sometimes postings.
  • Bookkeeping status and review workflow: The small set of process fields that makes “inbox-style” bookkeeping possible across objects.
  • Accounting periods: Period open/close/lock control data used across modules.

Sales (invoicing and receivables)

  • Sales invoices: Outgoing invoices that create revenue and a receivable until paid.
  • Sales invoice rows: Line-level intent that drives revenue account selection and VAT handling.

Purchasing (vendor invoices, payables, and posting intent)

  • Purchase invoices: Incoming invoices that create an expense or asset and a payable until paid.
  • Purchase posting specifications: The posting intent for purchases, typically split across accounts.

Cash and banking (imports, matching, and non-invoice events)

  • Bank accounts: The financial accounts that transactions belong to and that map to ledger accounts.
  • Bank transactions: Cash movements used for reconciliation and for non-invoice bookkeeping events.
  • Reconciliations: Append-only links and allocations that explain how cash movement settles invoices and journal transactions.

Evidence and audit support (documents)

  • Documents (evidence): Evidence files and metadata that keep postings auditable by period and counterparty.

Fixed assets (depreciation and disposals)

  • Fixed assets: The asset register used for depreciation and disposals.

Financing (loans and amortization)

  • Loans: Loan contracts and event logs that drive amortization and postings.

Payroll (employees and payroll runs)

  • Employees: Employee reference data used for payroll runs and postings.
  • Payroll runs: Month-based payroll run records that produce postings.

Inventory (stock and valuation)

  • Inventory items: Item master data used for stock movements and valuation.
  • Inventory movements: Append-only stock movement records used for audit and valuation.

Planning (budgets and variance)

  • Budgets: Budget lines keyed by account and period for variance reporting.
